0: Image copyright BP plc Image caption BP shut down production on Valhall and said it was moving all its staff off the field NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A potential major disaster in the North Sea has been narrowly averted after a large, unmanned barge went adrift in stormy high seas and came close to colliding with offshore oil platforms. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Eide Barge 33 missed the Valhall field by at least 1km (0.6 miles). NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR More than 300 oil workers were airlifted from the Norwegian sector of the North Sea after the high winds broke the barge's anchor. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Stormy weather in the area has seen waves topping 15m (50ft). NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A man died when a huge wave hit another rig earlier in the Troll field off Norway. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Forced shut down NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The strong winds tore the barge from its moorings and sent it towards BP's Valhall platform, located in the middle of the North Sea between Norway and the UK. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The oil and gas company was forced to shut down output and evacuate staff on board. ConocoPhillips also stopped production and evacuated crew from installations in the same area. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A spokeswoman for the Rescue Coordination Centre for southern Norway told the Reuters news agency that the danger posed by the barge was now over. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "There are no other installations between the barge and the coast of Norway," Borghild Eldoen said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright AP Image caption The Norwegian sector is thought to contain 54% of the North Sea's oil reserves NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "It is now up to the owners of the barge to stop it before it reaches the coast." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At one point fears about a collision increased when the barge - 110m in length and 30m wide - changed course and headed straight for Valhall, BP Norway spokesman Jan Erik Geirmo told the AFP news agency. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But in the event it floated away from the evacuated platforms. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Mr Geirmo said that a tug had been deployed to immobilise it - an operation which will be dangerous in such stormy conditions. He said the situation was now returning to normal and employees will progressively return to the platforms.
